newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Bonn, Brazil, S.Africa to push global eco policy.
newsitem.headline: Bonn, Brazil, S.Africa to push global eco policy.

text.p: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said on Wednesday that Germany, Brazil and South Africa would push at the United Nations for agreement on a global environmental policy to protect rain forests and ecosystems.
Kohl, passing through Brasilia on a 24-hour visit, said the three would join forces to place the issue on the agenda of a special U.N. general assembly next year.
"Cooperation on environmental policy is of the highest priority," Kohl told reporters.

"The three of us together, including South African President Nelson Mandela, and perhaps with Asian countries, will work to push for a global environmental policy at a special U.N. General Assembly next year."

The veteran German leader, who was on a three-nation Latin American tour accompanied by high-powered German businessmen, earlier lashed out at other Group of Seven countries for not doing enough to help protect the Amazon rain forest.
Bonn's ties with Brazil are essentially economic. But the environment plays a large role and Bonn is the single greatest contributor to a G7-backed pilot programme for the Amazon.
"For us it's important to give the (pilot program) a new boost, a new dynamism," Kohl said.

"I am extremely pleased to find here that (Brazilian) President (Fernando Henrique) Cardoso regards this problem like I do, that he knows that the preservation of the forests is one of the key issues for the future."
Cardoso was due to visit South Africa in November. Kohl said he expected one of the key items on the agenda would be a global environmental policy.
The German chancellor was due to leave Brazil later on Wednesday for Mexico.
